comments.commentBody: We can still vote. A wonderful referendum on Mr. Trump's approach to America. Have some faith in our better natures. There are more of us.

Exactly who WILL speak for working people in the days ahead? Trump, who has shown no actual interest in policy details and with minor exceptions endorses standard Republican trickle-down orthodoxy? Hillary, whose preconvention leftward zig is widely expected to be followed with a postconvention zag to the right? We can only hope that voters will ask, which party – on balance – has fewer thieves, clowns, zealots and corporate sock puppets. Vote for the party, not the candidate.

It is a message of fear, not hope; of anger, not love; of division, not unity. He is speaking not the better nature of our angels, but the darker demons of our prejudices.

We have seen these men before, and they bring darkness.

Following the rhetoric from beginning to the convention, I am convinced Trump has become a specialist in using the "Reptile Theory" as the basis for his rhetoric. His convention speech is a shining of example of this approach.
This is a trial technique that looks at the defendant's behavior, not the plaintiff's. It appeals to the "reptilian part of our brain" supposedly. Research this theory for more specifics.
In short, it invokes the record of safety of the defendant/other side. It focuses on anger. You are not safe, there is no law and order, and aren't you angry about it? You are not safe because Hillary and Obama have created the danger. I can make you safe. The Reptile Rhetorical approach delivered by a narcissist. Frightening.

A valid political campaign has to assert something positive rather than state opposition to the other party. This was the primary problem with the Al Gore and the John Kerry campaigns compared to that of President Obama (and even Hillary Clinton eight years ago) who was the first Democratic presidential candidate in many years to propose a platform in the affirmative rather than merely state opposition to the other party. Now the shoe is on the other foot and the Republican party including Mr. Trump simply state that they are against the other party, It will likely take the Republican party another 8 to 12 years of irrelevance in presidential politics before they create a new platform that offers something positive that demographic groups other than older scared white females and males can get behind.

Ask not what historical shift, what tremors in American culture, yielded up Mr. Trump’s moment from the depths of the national id. Face the facts. You, the press, in large part, did this. The amount of media coverage on this man-  every moment of every day- was and is inexcusable. As P.T. Barnum noted: "Without promotion, something terrible happens...nothing!"

To the white rabble who support him, Trump is the distillation of the enmity they hold for the black usurper who has ruled this country for the last eight years. Trump, the "Birther-King", will take this country back from blacks, Latinos, Muslims, Jews, immigrants and women.
For racists, it's clear to see what has occurred when you let a black man become president: you get lawlessness against police. Just ask Rudy Giuliani. Never mind that the police kill unarmed blacks over traffic misdemeanors, or for no other reason than being black.
No, Trump didn't win the nomination because of a bad economy or a misguided foreign policy. He didn't win because the middle class is fed up. Trump won by appealing to hate, bigotry and racism. The mad-dogs, chanting their venomous slogans inside the convention hall in Cleveland, were out for blood, not jobs.

"Mr. Trump’s nomination is also a referendum on the Republican Party, delivered by working people fed up with leaders who want their votes but don’t address their struggles.". just as Bernie's election race was a referendum delivered by the struggling students and workers who are fed up with leaders who want their votes but didn't address their struggles. There is a general and genuine anger of all the 'regular' people directed directly at the political class which enriches itself either with indifference or at the expense of the people. This has  been a Primary election based on disappointment, frustration and anger. "Throw the bums out" is the underlying theme.
I think all of us have understood that "Make America Great Again" really meant "Make America White Again."

Trump showed his empathy for the American people who have not benefitted from the fruits of globalism. He spoke to the people who are shocked and disgusted by our police being targeted in the streets and the instigators being feted by the white house. Trump spoke to our communities who are being asked to support unvetted immigrants in their communities and suffer the consequences of mistakes made. Trump spoke to those who do not live behind protective walls and want the government to protect them. He spoke to me.

I am confident that Trump achieved his purpose last night. He echoed the fears of his base, tamped down some appearances of excess (e.g., sending Hillary to jail, keeping out Muslims), and pasted over his oeuvre with a more difficult-to-parse claim that he is reprising Nixon's call to the "Silent Majority" and to "Bring-Us-Together-ism".

What I am not at all sure of is this: he advocated serious economically destabilizing goals, which are not even arguably targetted to the alleged problem, Big-Government expansion plans, and defense ideas that only exacerbate the first two.

Is he betting that he can stimulate fear so much during this campaign that voters will have no choice but to embrace his offer of the salvation that only he can render. I don't like to think that there may be an American majority that is willing to grasp in desperation at magical thinking, but in fact, I'm not sure.

What began as legitimation of racial and religious bigotry appears now to be a mystical campaign to deliver the country into a mythological past that never existed.

I'm truly tired of the narrative that says Trump rose to power because no one else was speaking for the working man. Trump rose to power because he spoke rather well, actually, both to and for a particular kind of working man--the white working man who doesn't have a whole lot going for him other than that he's white.

In hindsight, it's clear that everything, from Trump's birtherism to his remarks about a bleeding Megan Kelly, were expertly calculated to appeal to this particular kind of seething, resentful man. Trump's proud vulgarity is their own proud vulgarity, his anger is their anger. (Why there are any women supporting Trump is a puzzle; perhaps this stems from a masochism deep in the female psyche.) The men who support Trump deeply resent women and Blacks, or any other minorities who dare to long to succeed in America.

Obama's presidency undoubtedly brought this white male rage to the surface of the American political skin, but make no mistake, the poisonous pus was there long before Obama and globalization. Because of Trump, we can see with a gimlet eye that America has always harbored a significant minority of white males in whom there simmers a pathological brew of racism, misogyny and resentment.

The time has come for decent people everywhere to stop empathizing with Trump supporters. Defeat their man in November.

This begs the question: How did/has the media dodged the FCC's Equal Time Protection regulations for all the other candidates? Trump has crowed that the media saturation made it possible for him to spend very little on his primary run. The Times, and every other media source, must correct this course for the rest of this sorry campaign cycle. It is imperative that Clinton get equal media treatment to Trump. Becoming an informed voter is absolutely crucial.
